title: 111_hr5782
content: The Act is titled "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Treas-HUD and OPIC Programs Act". It includes sections on Treasury savings, HUD savings, and OPIC termination. Treasury savings involve limitations on funds for the Bureau of the Public Debt and Electronic pay stubs for Treasury employees. HUD savings include rent subsidies under the HUD section 8 housing choice voucher program for one-person households. OPIC termination is also addressed in the Act. Title I of the Act focuses on Treasury savings, including limitations on funds for the Bureau of the Public Debt and the Financial Management Service. It also addresses the implementation of electronic pay stubs for Treasury employees. SEC. 102 of the Act mandates electronic pay stubs for Treasury employees receiving pay through electronic funds transfer starting in fiscal year 2011. SEC. 103 terminates the advance payment of earned income credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with various conforming amendments to related sections. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. HUD Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher program rent subsidies for one-person households are addressed in Title II. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to provide specific assistance for single person families under section 8(o). The payment standard for a single person in an efficiency dwelling unit is established, and larger units are not eligible. Additionally, the OPIC Repeal Act is introduced in Title III. The "OPIC Repeal Act" is cited as the short title for the termination of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation's authority to issue insurance, guaranties, loans, and acquire securities under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is terminated. Existing contracts and agreements are preserved. The OPIC is abolished effective September 30, 2011. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation is abolished, and its functions are transferred to the Agency for International Development until existing contracts expire. The Administrator will wind up the Corporation's affairs, and certain authorities are repealed. Upon the repeal of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, its funds will be transferred to the Administrator of the Agency for International Development for use in carrying out the Corporation's functions. Any remaining balances will be deposited in the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts after the expiration of existing contracts. SEC. 303. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. Prior determinations, regulations, and contracts issued under the provisions of law before the repeal shall remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or a court. The repeal will not affect pending proceedings on the effective date. The proposed rulemaking, pending on the effective date of the repeal, will continue before the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. No insurance, reinsurance, guarantee, or loan may be issued under any pending applications. Proceedings related to functions performed by the Administrator of the Agency for International Development after the repeal will be continued. Orders issued in these proceedings will remain in effect until modified, terminated, superseded, or revoked. The Administrator of the Agency for International Development may issue regulations for the transfer of proceedings, and actions will continue as provided in subsection (e). Actions under this section will not affect ongoing suits, which will proceed as if the section had not been enacted. Liabilities and proceedings involving the Overseas Private Investment Corporation will not be affected by the repeal. Before the effective date of the repeal, ongoing suits involving the Overseas Private Investment Corporation will continue with the Administrator of the Agency for International Development substituted or added as a party. Orders and actions of the Administrator will be subject to judicial review as if issued by the Corporation, following the same statutory requirements. The Administrator of the Agency for International Development will exercise the function previously held by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. SEC. 304. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Title 5, United States Code is amended by removing references to positions at the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Additionally, amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 by removing certain subsections. Amendments are made to various sections of different acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Export Enhancement Act of 1988, by striking and redesignating certain subsections and paragraphs. Amendments are made to different sections of acts by striking and redesignating certain paragraphs and clauses. Amendments are made to various sections of acts by striking and redesignating specific clauses and paragraphs. Amendments are made to various sections of acts by striking specific clauses and paragraphs, including provisions repealed from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation Amendments Act of 1981, Taiwan Relations Act, Support for East European Democracy Act, title 31 of the United States Code, African Growth and Opportunity Act, and Africa: Seeds of Hope Act. Amendments and repeals made by this subsection, including changes to sections of various acts, will take effect on October 1, 2011.
